ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General knowledge of language contact in the Ancient Near East and some principles of linguistics.

Overview of many different languages in the Ancient Near East and their contact history, introduction to different major areas of inquiry in linguistics (phonology, semantics, syntax, morphology, etc.)

As far as raw knowledge goes, this class provided as much knowledge as my brain could saturate, and some. Understanding how languages and writing systems and related yet separate, and these living, breathing languages evolve, thrive, and ultimately die.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the weekly readings and writing assignments. I would have preferred more discussion in class.

This course offers a solid introduction to studying ancient languages. The textbook is very thorough, but the coursework is accessible to students of any linguistic background (I had none). Some translation exercises/study of the actual languages might have been useful.  The course format could be a bit repetitive at times, but the textual examples that we explored in a few meetings were engaging and helped bring the topics to life.

The course basically catered to my level of experience with linguistics and also played to my interests. A lot of the morphological and grammatical stuff went right over my head, but that was okay. I took the pieces that interested me the most and ran, and that was okay. I think that spending a few classes on explaining basic linguistic terms would be nice, but we didn't do that because there were so many grad students in the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminars were interesting, but a little long and sometimes hard to fully engage with over Zoom. I think it could've been improved if we had more time to discuss language contact instead of mostly having lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're interested in Ancient Near Eastern languages and have a background in linguistics I would recommend this class. But if not, I think this class might be a little hard to follow.

I would recommend this class, but I would note that it will likely be more useful or interesting to you if you have studied one of the languages under investigation. I came into the course expecting more of a balance between translation and linguistic analysis, but it turned out to be more of a broad introduction to the latter. There is also much less class time devoted to discussion than in a typical seminar-style class.
Yes- this course was truly fascinating and the workload and difficulty was manageable, regardless of your level.

extras.title:
LING 503 01/NELC 103 01/LING 103 01
        Language in the Ancient World
